verses.verse: (vv 21, 23|EZK 41:2123; Ezek 40.2, 3, 9, 17) Then he brought me to the nave and measured the posts; on each side six cubits was the depth of the posts. (Compare Gk: Heb tent)

(1 Kings 6.2, 17; 2 Chr 3.3) The width of the entrance was ten cubits, and the sidewalls of the entrance were five cubits on either side. He measured the length of the nave, forty cubits, and its width, twenty cubits.

(v 1|EZK 41:1; Ezek 40.16) Then he went into the inner room and measured the posts of the entrance, two cubits, and the width of the entrance, six cubits, and the sidewalls (Gk: Heb width) of the entrance, seven cubits.
(1 Kings 6.20; 2 Chr 3.8) He measured the depth of the room, twenty cubits, and its width, twenty cubits, beyond the nave. And he said to me, “This is the most holy place.”
Then he measured the wall of the temple, six cubits thick, and the width of the side chambers, four cubits, all around the temple.

(1 Kings 6.5, 6) The side chambers were in three stories, one over another, thirty in each story. There were offsets (Gk: Heb they entered) all around the wall of the temple to serve as supports for the side chambers so that they should not be supported by the wall of the temple.

(1 Kings 6.8) The passageway (Cn: Heb it was surrounded) of the side chambers widened from story to story, for the structure was supplied with a stairway all around the temple. For this reason the structure became wider from story to story. One ascended from the bottom story to the uppermost story by way of the middle one.
(Ezek 40.5) I saw also that the temple was on a raised platform all around; the foundations of the side chambers measured a full reed of six long cubits high.
(v 11) The thickness of the outer wall of the side chambers was five cubits, and the free space between the side chambers of the temple
(Ezek 40.17) and the chambers of the court was a width of twenty cubits all around the temple on every side.
(v 9) The side chambers opened onto the area left free, one door toward the north and another door toward the south, and the width of the part that was left free was five cubits all around.

(vv 13–15|EZK 41:13–15; Ezek 42.1) The building that was facing the temple yard on the west side was seventy cubits deep, and the wall of the building was five cubits thick all around and its width ninety cubits.
(vv 13–15|EZK 41:13–15; Ezek 40.47) Then he measured the temple, one hundred cubits deep, and the yard and the building with its walls, one hundred cubits deep,
(Ezek 40.47) also the width of the east front of the temple and the yard, one hundred cubits.

(v 25|EZK 41:25; Ezek 40.6; 42.1, 10, 13) Then he measured the width of the building facing the yard at the west, together with its galleries (Cn: Meaning of Heb uncertain) on either side, one hundred cubits. The nave of the temple’s interior and the outer (Gk: Heb of the court) vestibule

(vv 15, 25, 26|EZK 41:152526; 1 Kings 6.15; Ezek 40.16; 42.3) were paneled, (Gk: Heb the thresholds) and all around all three had windows with recessed (Cn Compare Gk: Meaning of Heb uncertain) frames. Facing the threshold, the temple was paneled with wood all around, from the floor up to the windows (now the windows were covered).
On the space above the door, even to the inner room, and on the outside and on all the walls all around in the inner room and the nave there was a pattern. (Heb measures)
(1 Kings 6.29; 7.36; 2 Chr 3.5; Ezek 40.16) It was formed of cherubim and palm trees, a palm tree between cherub and cherub. Each cherub had two faces:

(Ezek 1.10; 10.14) a human face turned toward the palm tree on the one side, and the face of a young lion turned toward the palm tree on the other side. They were carved on the whole temple all around;
from the floor to the area above the door, cherubim and palm trees were carved on the wall. (Cn: Heb and the wall)
(v 1|EZK 41:1; 1 Kings 6.33; Ezek 40.9, 14, 16) The doorposts of the nave were square. In front of the holy place was something resembling

(Ex 30.1, 8; Ezek 44.16; Mal 1.7, 12; Rev 8.3) an altar of wood, three cubits high, two cubits long, and two cubits wide; (Gk: Heb lacks two cubits wide) its corners, its base, (Gk: Heb length) and its walls were of wood. He said to me, “This is the table that stands before the LORD.”
(vv 1, 4|EZK 41:14; 1 Kings 6.31-35) The nave and the holy place had each a double door.
The doors had two leaves apiece, two swinging leaves for each door.
On the doors of the nave were carved cherubim and palm trees, such as were carved on the walls, and there was a canopy of wood in front of the vestibule outside.

(v 16|EZK 41:16; Ezek 40.9, 16, 48) And there were recessed windows and palm trees on either side, on the sidewalls of the vestibule. (Cn: Heb vestibule. And the side chambers of the temple and the canopies)
